title: Sacerdotal state
text:
A sacerdotal state is a state whose <a href="Head%20of%20state">head</a> is also an ecclesiastical leader designated by a religious body. An example of this kind of state is the <a href="Vatican%20City">Vatican City</a>, whose head of state is the <a href="pope">pope</a> of the <a href="Catholic%20Church">Catholic Church</a>. <a href="Andorra">Andorra</a> operates under a semi-sacerdotal system, as one of its co-heads of state is the <a href="bishop%20of%20Urgell">bishop of Urgell</a>, while the other is the <a href="president%20of%20France">president of France</a>. However unlike the Vatican, the <a href="co-princes%20of%20Andorra">co-princes of Andorra</a> are not closely involved in the government.
In the past it was common for <a href="bishop">bishop</a>s to assume civil as well as clerical power and rule as <a href="prince-bishop">prince-bishop</a>s. This was common in the <a href="Holy%20Roman%20Empire">Holy Roman Empire</a>, where three of the seven <a href="Prince-elector">imperial electors</a> were prince-archbishops (<a href="Elector%20of%20Trier">Trier</a>, <a href="Electorate%20of%20Mainz">Mainz</a> and <a href="Elector%20of%20Cologne">Cologne</a>). After the <a href="Peace%20of%20Westphalia">Peace of Westphalia</a> certain prince-bishoprics became bi-confessional and alternated between Catholic bishops and <a href="Protestantism">Protestant</a> <a href="Diocesan%20administrator">administrators</a>.
Since the <a href="English%20Reformation">English Reformation</a>, <a href="English%20monarchs">English</a> and <a href="British%20monarchs">British monarchs</a> have held the title <a href="supreme%20governor%20of%20the%20Church%20of%20England">supreme governor of the Church of England</a>, signifying leadership of the <a href="state%20church">state church</a>. The subsequent <a href="personal%20union">personal</a> and legal unions with <a href="Laws%20in%20Wales%20Acts%201535%20and%201542">Wales</a>, <a href="Acts%20of%20Union%201707">Scotland</a> and <a href="Acts%20of%20Union%201800">Ireland</a> did not extend <a href="Anglicanism">Anglicanism</a>'s status of state church to these lands. Thus in the <a href="United%20Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>, the monarch is the <a href="head%20of%20state">head of state</a> and also the leader of the state church in <a href="England">England</a> and its <a href="Crown%20dependencies">Crown dependencies</a>.
The <a href="Supreme%20Leader%20of%20Iran">Supreme Leader of Iran</a> is elected for life by a body consisting of senior <a href="Twelver">Twelver</a> clerics. The supreme leader, known as an <a href="ayatollah">ayatollah</a>, is the spiritual leader of the country as well as a powerful political figure with wide-ranging powers and his own military force.
In the past, <a href="Tibet%20%281912%E2%80%931951%29">Tibet</a> was ruled by the <a href="Dalai%20Lama">Dalai Lama</a>s, political leaders who were symbolic religious leaders but had no formal position in religious organisations, so not being sacerdotal.
<a href="Prince-Bishopric%20of%20Montenegro">Prince-Bishopric of Montenegro</a> was an <a href="Eastern%20Orthodox">Eastern Orthodox</a> ecclesiastical principality that existed from 1516 until 1852 in the <a href="Balkans">Balkans</a> during the <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>'s rule over the most of the region.
